Item.Name: Abstract
Item.Label: Description
Item.Data: This year, 1990, is the 75th anniversary of <highlight>Mary</highlight> <highlight>Jobe's</highlight> election as a Fellow of the Royal Geographical Society in recognition of her explorations in the Canadian Rockies. She had already been selected for membership of the American Geographical Society, and in 1925 the Geographic Board of Canada named a peak in the Canadian Rockies in her honour (Mt <highlight>Jobe</highlight>). Few people today have heard of <highlight>Mary</highlight> <highlight>Jobe</highlight> <highlight>Akeley</highlight> (as she became after her marriage), but she was a remarkable woman who made significant contributions to the exploration and mapping of the Canadian Rockies. Her most ambitious undertaking was an expedition to reach-and if possible to scale-a previously unexplored peak far to the north-west of Mt Robson near the British Columbia/Alberta border. The map which she produced of the region between Mt Robson and Mt Sir Alexander (as the new peak later was named) was the only relatively reliable source of information about the area for a number of years. This is an appropriate time, then, to review the geographical achievements of <highlight>Mary</highlight> <highlight>Jobe</highlight> <highlight>Akeley</highlight>, one of a relatively small number of women in history who braved the physical and mental challenges of exploring the unknown.

Title.TitleFull: Mary Jobe Akeley's Explorations in the Canadian Rockies
